title: 112_hr1947
content: The Act is titled the "Post 9/11 Troops to Teachers Enhancement Act" and includes provisions regarding years of service requirements and stipends. The "Post 9/11 Troops to Teachers Enhancement Act" amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include a provision where individuals who serve at least 90 continuous days on active duty after September 11, 2001, in the Armed Forces are eligible for certain benefits. Individuals who serve in the Armed Forces and are discharged or released under honorable conditions, including retirement, transfer to reserve, or further service in a reserve unit. The curr_chunk revises the length of service required for individuals transitioning to a reserve component of the Armed Forces from 6 years to 4 years. The curr_chunk amends the definition of local educational agency and public charter schools under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also establishes an Advisory Board under Chapter A of subpart 1 of part C of title II of the Act. The Post 9/11 Troops to Teachers Enhancement Act establishes an Advisory Board composed of representatives from the Department of Defense, Department of Education, State offices, and veteran service organizations. The Advisory Board established under the Post 9/11 Troops to Teachers Enhancement Act includes representatives from veteran service organizations. Their duties involve collecting feedback on best practices for recruitment, ensuring awareness of the Program in high-need educational agencies, and coordinating with other education programs. The Advisory Board under the Post 9/11 Troops to Teachers Enhancement Act collects feedback on recruitment best practices, promotes Program awareness, and coordinates with other education programs. They prepare and submit annual reports to relevant Senate and House Committees, including information on Advisory Board activities and Program participants. The Program collects data on participating States, local educational agencies, schools, grade levels, subjects taught, retention rates, demographic information, and stipend/bonus review for evaluation. The Program evaluates stipend and bonus availability for participants and makes recommendations for improving recruitment and retention efforts, policy changes, and overall program effectiveness.
